abstracts.cdata!:
The Highways Rehabilitation Project
            (HRP) for Pakistan had a satisfactory outcome with the
            Project Development Objectives (PDO) and achievement of
            outcome indicators considered to be significantly relevant,
            and satisfactory overall design rating for relevance and
            implementation progress, in spite of the extension of the
            closing date, with the project meeting all its physical
            targets. The original project parameters were revised, with
            changes in the main beneficiaries, project components,
            additional financing and an extension of the closing date of
            the project. The outcomes of the HRP led to the realization
            that lump-sum contracts were a success, leading to much
            lower overall construction completion costs when compared to
            traditional item-rate contracts. The HRP experience showed
            that addressing sector policy reforms in investment
            operations is a rather difficult undertaking. It also
            highlighted the inadequacy of the price adjustment
            mechanism, and construction industry constraints.
